abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory. There are increases in graduate students
            trained at high levels of quality, enhanced capacity for
            such training in the future, and impressive research results
            emanating from the project. Laboratory management has
            improved and more effective technology transfer strategies
            are beginning. Overall, the project significantly
            contributed to Chinese research and advanced education
            capacities and to the modernization of thinking about
            research, education, and laboratory equipment. Key lessons
            learned from this project include: It is possible to
            accelerate China's scientific and technological
            development with appropriate resources and careful planning,
            and by training more graduate students at international
            levels of proficiency. It is difficult to transfer
            managerial experience acquired in other countries to China.
            Scarcity of equipment made the community maximize the amount
            of new equipment purchased, at the expense of acquiring
            adequate supplies of spare parts and consumables for the
            proper operation of that equipment. The sharing of major
            facilities at research and teaching institutions is hampered
            by the compartmentalized organizational structure within the
            science and technology community. Disseminating managerial
            know-how within and among laboratories is slow; more
            efficient means should have been adopted from the beginning.
            The Programme Advisory Group should have adopted a role akin
            to that of a managerial Principal Investigator.
